contentrichtext.text: [[Image:Sir Hugh Trenchard (cropped).jpg|thumb|200px|Hugh Trenchard, <br>1st Viscount Trenchard]] '''Viscount Trenchard''', of [[Wolfeton]] in the County of Dorset, is a title in the [[Peerage of the United Kingdom]]. It was created in 1936 for [[Marshal of the Royal Air Force]], [[Hugh Trenchard, 1st Viscount Trenchard|Hugh Trenchard, 1st Baron Trenchard]]. He had already been created a '''Baronet''', of Wolfeton in the County of Dorset, in the [[Baronetage of the United Kingdom]] in 1919 and '''Baron Trenchard''', of Wolfeton in the County of Dorset, in 1930, also in the Peerage of the United Kingdom. His second son, the second Viscount, held junior ministerial positions from 1979 to 1983 in the [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative]] administration of [[Margaret Thatcher]]. {{As of|2010}} the titles are held by the latter's son, the third Viscount, who succeeded in 1987. In 2004 he replaced the recently deceased [[Nicholas Vivian, 6th Baron Vivian|Lord Vivian]] as one of the ninety elected [[hereditary peer]]s that are allowed to remain in the [[House of Lords]] after the passing of the [[House of Lords Act 1999]]. Lord Trenchard sits on the [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative]] benches. The family seat is Standon Lordship, near [[Ware, Hertfordshire|Ware]], [[Hertfordshire]]. ==Viscounts Trenchard (1936)== *[[Hugh Trenchard, 1st Viscount Trenchard|Hugh Montague Trenchard, 1st Viscount Trenchard]] (1873–1956) *[[Thomas Trenchard, 2nd Viscount Trenchard]] (1923–1987) *[[Hugh Trenchard, 3rd Viscount Trenchard]] (b. 1951) The [[heir apparent]] is the present holder's son Hon. Alexander Thomas Trenchard (b. 1978), who was jailed for 30 months on 3 February 2011 for defrauding his employer, Tesco, out of £355,000.
